meanings.def: money that somebody agrees to pay if a person accused of a crime does not appear at their trial. When bail has been arranged, the accused person is allowed to go free until the trial.
examples: Can anyone put up bail for you?
on bail He committed another offence while he was out on bail (= after bail had been agreed).
For very serious crimes, it is hard to get bail.
She couldn't get bail and now she's lost those 20 months she spent on remand.
She has been granted conditional bail.
Rosenthal is currently free on bail.
The accused were held without bail.
The police were successful in opposing bail.
They were released on police bail pending further enquiries.
He was sent to a bail hostel until the case came to court.

meanings.def: either of the two small pieces of wood on top of each set of three wooden posts (called stumps)
to fail to appear at your trial after you have paid money to be allowed to go free until the trial
examples: He skipped bail and went on the run for two weeks.

idioms.def: to fail to appear at your trial after you have paid money to be allowed to go free until the trial
examples: He skipped bail and went on the run for two weeks.
be bailed to do something He was bailed to appear in court on 15 March.
be bailed He was bailed on a minor drugs charge.

meanings.def: to leave a place, especially quickly
examples: Sorry, I really have to bail.

meanings.def: to approach somebody and talk to them, often when they do not want this
